facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 23, 1960, of the Mysore High Court in Second Appeal No. 61 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by-special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 23, 1960, of the Mysore High Court in Second Appeal No. 61 of 1954.

facts.text: Special leave to appeal granted by Supreme Court on April 20, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave granted by this Court on April 20, 1961, is directed against the concurrent decisions of the courts below

facts.text: Lease dated October 26, 1914, executed between predecessors-in-interest of the parties.

anchor.surface_text: The controversy between the parties depends upon the true construction of the lease dated October 26, 1914, executed between the predecessors-in-interest

facts.text: N. J. Gamodia of Bombay took on lease a piece of agricultural land measuring about 4-1/2 acres belonging to Gurupadappa of Devangere City for erecting a Ginning and Pressing Cotton Factory.

anchor.surface_text: One N. J. Gamodia of Bombay took on lease a piece of agricultural land measuring about 4-1/2 acres belonging to one Gurupadappa of Devangere City for the purpose

facts.text: First period of lease: 20 years commencing from October 1, 1914, to September 30, 1934, annual rent Rs. 350/- in advance.

anchor.surface_text: For the 1st period of 20  twenty  years commencing from the 1st October, 1914, and ending on the 30th day of September, 1934, you shall pay to me Rs. 350/-

facts.text: After 20 years, lessee at liberty to continue lease as long as desired, paying Rs. 400/- for first 10 years from Oct 1, 1934 to Sep 30, 1944, then Rs. 500/- per annum.

anchor.surface_text: After the expiration of the said period of 20  twenty  years mentioned in the 1st clause hereby you shall be at liberty to continue the lease of the said land

facts.text: Lessor agrees not to call upon lessee to give up possession as long as lessee desires to keep it, observing terms.

anchor.surface_text: But I agree and bind myself not to call upon you at any time to give up the possession of the said land and the said road as long as you may desire

facts.text: Lessee at liberty to erect buildings, factories, etc., and make alterations; lessor no objection.

anchor.surface_text: You are at full liberty to erect, as many buildings, godowns, factories, bungalows and other structures etc. as you may desire on the land hereby leased

facts.text: Lessee entitled to sublet or re-let the land.

anchor.surface_text: You shall be always entitled and have full liberty to sublet or re-let the said land together with the said road for any purpose to any other person

facts.text: Lease binding on heirs, executors, administrators, successors and assigns of both parties.

anchor.surface_text: This lease is binding on me, my heirs, executors, administrators, successors and assigns as well as on your heirs, executors, administrators, successors and assigns.

facts.text: N. J. Gamodia died in 1916 leaving a will appointing executors.

anchor.surface_text: The said lessee, N. J. Gamodia died in 1916 leaving a will appointing executors to look after his affairs.

facts.text: Executors assigned the lease to second defendant, Gamodia Factories Limited, by deed dated November 27, 1933.

anchor.surface_text: The executors assigned the lease to the second defendant, Gamodia Factories Limited by a deed dated November27, 1933.

facts.text: Assignee continued to pay rent to lessor Gurupadappa till his death in May 1939.

anchor.surface_text: The assignee like the original tenant continued to pay the stipulated rentto the lessor Guru-padappa till his death which occurred in May, 1939.

facts.text: Second defendant assigned leasehold interest to first defendant by deed dated May 30, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: The second defendant in its turn assigned its leasehold interest to the first defendant by a deed dated May 30, 1944.

facts.text: Leasehold property contains factory, buildings and residential quarters.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that the leasehold property contains factory, buildings and residential quarters.

facts.text: After lessor's death, his two widows continued to receive rent from lessees.

anchor.surface_text: After the lessors death his two widows continued to receive rent from the lessees as usual.

facts.text: Plaintiff is adopted son of original lessor, minor till some time in 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff is the adopted son of the original lessor and was a minor till some time in 1949.

facts.text: Plaintiff issued notices to defendants to terminate tenancy on grounds: tenancy at will and assignment contravening lease terms.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff sought to terminate the tenancy by issuing notices to the defendants on, the ground  1  that the lease had created a tenancy at will

facts.text: Defendants did not vacate after notices, leading to suit for ejectment.

anchor.surface_text: As the defendants did not vacate the premises and deliver possession of them to the plaintiff, in terms of the notice aforesaid, he instituted the suit

facts.text: First defendant resisted suit claiming permanent tenancy, not tenancy at will.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was. resisted by the first defendant principally on the ground that the lease created not a tenancy at will as claimed by the plaintiff but a permanent tenancy

facts.text: Trial court decreed suit for ejectment, held lease for 20 years certain, then tenancy at will.

anchor.surface_text: The trial court held that it was a lease for 20 years certain, ,and on the efflux of that period on October 26, 1934, the second defendant became a tenant at will

facts.text: Lower appellate court affirmed trial court, dismissed appeal with modifications.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the defendants, the lower appellate court affirmed the finding of the trial court and dismissed the appeal with this modification

facts.text: Mysore High Court dismissed second appeal, held tenancy for indefinite period valid for lifetime of lessee and transferees, but assignment to first defendant not binding on plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: On second appeal by the first defendant, the High Court dismissed the appeal with costs, but modified. the findings of the two courts below in so far as it held that after the lapse

facts.text: High Court refused certificate for appeal on March 29, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The first defendant made an application to the High Court for the necessary certificate of fitness for coming up in appeal to this court but the High Court by its order dated March 29, 1961

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave on April 20, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: As time was running against the first defendant, he hurried up to this court by a petition for special leave to appeal dated April 10, 1961. On April 20, 1961

facts.text: Supreme Court holds the lease created a permanent tenancy.

anchor.surface_text: That being so, it must be held that the lease deed evidences an intention to create a permanent lease.

facts.text: Original lessor accepted assignment to second defendant during his lifetime.

anchor.surface_text: the original lessor in his lifetime had accepted the assignment of the lease in favour of the second. defendant.

facts.text: Plaintiff instituted suit for declaration that defendants were tenants at will and possession wrongful after notice.

anchor.surface_text: he instituted the suit giving rise to the present appeal for a declaration that the defendants were tenants at will and that their possession after service of notice was wrongful
Appeal by-special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 23, 1960, of the Mysore High Court in Second Appeal No. 61 of 1954.
This appeal by special leave granted by this Court on April 20, 1961, is directed against the concurrent decisions of the courts below
As time was running against the first defendant, he hurried up to this court by a petition for special leave to appeal dated April 10, 1961. On April 20, 1961

holdings.reasoning_summary: Construing lease deed as a whole reveals intention for permanent tenancy: for building purposes without fixed period post-20 years, presumption of permanency applies, reinforced by heritability and assignability clauses, lessor's covenant not to terminate, lessee's unilateral surrender right does not rebut presumption

holdings.text: we ruled that we shall not permit that contention to be raised here

anchor.surface_text: but as that defence has not been raised in the pleadings of the defendant and as that point has not been canvassed in the High Court, we ruled that we shall not permit that contention to be raised here.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defence under Mysore Rent Act not raised in pleadings or argued before High Court

holdings.text: the presumption in favour of the transaction creating a permanent lease cannot be held to have been rebutted by a stipulation in favour of the tenant having the right to surrender the lease at his choice

anchor.surface_text: That being so, in our opinion, on a true and proper construction of the lease deed, the presumption in favour of the transaction creating a permanent lease cannot be held to have been rebutted by a stipulation in favour of the tenant having the right to surrender the lease at his choice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lessee's unilateral option to surrender after initial period benefits lessee only, does not confer corresponding right on lessor or derogate from permanency otherwise intended

precedents.case_name: Janaki Nath Roy v Dina Nath Kundu

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons aforesaid, it must be held that the High Court was in error in holding that the present case is governed by the decision of the Bombay High Court in I.L.R. 1954 Bom. 448. That decision was, with all respect, entirely companyrect on the terms of the document then before the companyrt. That being so, in our opinion, on a true and proper companystruction of the lease deed, the presumption in favour of the transaction creating a permanent lease cannot be held to have been rebutted by a stipulation in favour of the tenant having the right to surrender the lease at his choice.

outcome.relief_summary: Lease deed held to create permanent tenancy; High Court held in error; suit for ejectment fails
